description: First attested use in 1625–1635, apparently from association with shark (verb), or otherwise directly from German Schurke (“rogue, knave”).

entries.meaning: One who shirks, who avoids a duty or responsibility.

verbs.description: shirk (third-person singular simple present shirks, present participle shirking, simple past and past participle shirked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To avoid, especially a duty, responsibility, etc.; to stay away from.
(intransitive) To evade an obligation; to avoid the performance of duty, as by running away.
examples: If you have a job, don't shirk from it by staying off work.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To procure by petty fraud and trickery; to obtain by mean solicitation.
examples: You that never heard the call of any vocation,  […]  that shirk living from others, but time from yourselves.
